tn.text: Paul travels to Ephesus.

The "upper country" was an area of Asia which today is part of modern-day Turkey to the north of Ephesus. Paul must have traveled by land around the top of the Aegean sea in order to come to Ephesus (also in Turkey today) which is directly east of Corinth by sea.
This phrase is used here to mark the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
"traveled through"
This means to have the Holy Spirit come upon them.

tn.ref: we did not even hear about the Holy Spirit
tn.text: "we have not even heard about the Holy Spirit"
Here the words "They," "you," and "they" refer to certain disciples in the city of Ephesus. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:19:03|19:1]])
The word "him" refers to John.

tn.ref: Into what then were you baptized?
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "What kind of baptism did you receive?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
You can translate this as a complete sentence. AT: "We received the kind of baptism about which John taught" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
You can translate the abstract noun "repentance" as the verb "repent." AT: "the baptism that people requested when they wanted to repent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here "the one" refers to Jesus.
This means to come after John the Baptist in time and not following after him physically.
Paul continues staying in Ephesus.
Here "people" refers to the disciples in Ephesus who were talking with Paul. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:19:03|19:1]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "they received baptism" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: in the name of the Lord Jesus
tn.text: Here "name" refers to Jesus' power and authority. AT: "as believers in the Lord Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"placed his hands on them." He probably placed his hands on their shoulders or heads. AT: "placed his hands on their heads as he prayed" (UDB)

tn.ref: they spoke in other languages and prophesied
tn.text: Unlike in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:01|2:3-4]], there are no details of who  understood their messages.

tn.ref: In all they were about twelve men
tn.text: This tells how many men were baptized. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"12 men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Paul went into the synagogue and spoke boldly for the space of three months
tn.text: "Paul regularly attended the synagogue meetings for three months and spoke there boldly"
"convincing people of the truth"
Here "kingdom" stands for God's rule as king. AT: "concerning God's rule as king" or "concerning how God would show himself as king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: some Jews were hardened and disobedient
tn.text: To stubbornly refuse to believe is spoken of as though the people were becoming hard and unable to move. AT: "some Jews were stubborn and did not believe" or "some Jews stubbornly refused to accept and obey the message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: to speak evil of the way of Christ before the crowd
tn.text: What Christ wants people to believe is spoken of as though it were a road that a person travels. The phrase, "the way," seems to have been a title for Christianity at the time. AT: "to speak evil about Christianity to the crowd" or "to speak to the crowd evil things about Christ and what he taught about God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:bible:notes:act:09:01|9:2]])
"to speak bad things about"

tn.ref: in the lecture hall of Tyrannus
tn.text: "in the large room where Tyrannus had taught people"
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: all who lived in Asia heard
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Paul shared the gospel with many people throughout all of Asia or 2) Paul's message went out to all of Asia from Ephesus by the Ephesians as well as people who visited Ephesus and came from all over Asia.
Here "word" stands for a message. AT: "the message about the Lord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the words "them" and "they" refer to those who were sick.

tn.ref: God was doing mighty deeds by the hands of Paul
tn.text: Here "hands" stands for Paul's whole person. AT: "God was causing Paul to do miracles" or "God was doing miracles through Paul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: so that even the sick were healed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "so that he healed the sick" or "so that even the sick became healthy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The words "the sick" can made clear. AT: "sick people" or "those who were sick" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: when they took handkerchiefs and aprons from Paul's body
tn.text: These were probably cloth items that Paul had worn or used. AT: "when they touched handkerchiefs and aprons that Paul had worn while working"
cloths worn around the head
clothing worn on the front of the body to protect the clothes of people
This is the beginning of another event that happened while Paul was in Ephesus. It is about Jewish exorcists.
people who send evil spirits from people or places

tn.ref: took the name of Jesus for their own use
tn.text: Even though they did not believe in Jesus, they tried to use his name as one of their magic words.
Here "name" refers to Jesus' power and authority. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: They spoke it over those who had evil spirits
tn.text: "They spoke the name of Jesus to the evil spirits that had taken control over people"
"those who were under the influence of evil spirits"

tn.ref: by the Jesus whom Paul preaches
tn.text: "Jesus" was a common name at the time, so these exorcists wanted people to know of whom they spoke.
This stands for the power and authority of Jesus. AT: "by the authority of Jesus" or "by the power of Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Those who did this were the seven sons of a Jewish chief priest, Sceva
tn.text: This is background information about the exorcists. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Jesus I know, and Paul I know
tn.text: "I know Jesus and Paul" or "I know Jesus, and I know Paul"

The spirit asked this question to emphasize that the exorcists had no authority over evil spirits. AT: "but I do not know you!" or "but you have no authority over me!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion|Rhetorical Question]])

tn.ref: The evil spirit in the man leaped
tn.text: This means that the evil spirit caused the man whom it was controlling to leap on the exorcists.
This refers to people who send evil spirits from people or places. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:19:13|19:13]].
The exorcists fled with their clothes ripped off them.

tn.ref: the name of the Lord Jesus was honored
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "they honored the name of the Lord Jesus" or "they considered the name of the Lord Jesus to be great" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This stands for the power and authority of Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This ends the story about the Jewish exorcists. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_endofstory]])
"collected their books." The word "books" refers to scrolls on which magical incantations and formulas were written.
"in front of everyone"
"the value of the books" or "the value of the scrolls"
"50,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
A "piece of silver" was the approximate daily wage for a common laborer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])

tn.ref: So the word of the Lord spread very widely in powerful ways
tn.text: "So because of these powerful deeds, more and more people heard the message about the Lord Jesus"
Paul talks about going Jerusalem but does not leave Ephesus yet.
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Luke starts to tell a new part of the story.

tn.ref: Paul completed his ministry in Ephesus
tn.text: "Paul completed the work that God had for him to do in Ephesus"
Possible meanings are 1) Paul decided with the help of the Holy Spirit or 2) Paul decided within his own spirit, which means he made up his mind.

Achaia was the Roman province in which Corinth was located. It was the largest city in southern Greece and the capital of the province. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:18:12|18:12]].
"I must also travel to Rome"
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: But he himself stayed in Asia for a while
tn.text: It is made explicit in the next few verses that Paul remains in Ephesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is repeated for emphasis.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
Luke tells about a riot that broke out while Paul was in Ephesus.
Demetrius is introduced to the story. Verse 24 introduces background information about Demetrius. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

Ephesus had a large temple dedicated to the goddess Diana, sometimes translated as the Greek name "Artemis." Diana was a false goddess of fertility. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])

tn.ref: there arose a great disturbance in Ephesus concerning the Way
tn.text: This is a summary opening statement.
"the people became very upset"
This was a term used to refer to Christianity. See how you translated this title in [[:en:bible:notes:act:09:01|9:2]].
The use of the words "a certain" introduces a new person in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
a craftsman who works with silver metal to make statues and jewelry
This is the name of a man. Demetrius was a silversmith in Ephesus who was against Paul and the local church. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
"made a lot of money for those who made the idols"
Demetrius continues to speak to the craftsmen.
"You have come to know and understand that"

Paul's stopping people from worshiping idols is spoken of as though Paul were literally turning the people in a different direction. AT: "caused many people to stop worshiping the local gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He is saying that there are no gods that are made with hands
tn.text: Here the word "hands" can refer to the whole person. AT: He is saying that there are no gods that are made with the hands of people" or "He is saying that the idols that people make are not real gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: that our trade will no longer be needed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "that the people will no longer want to buy idols from us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the temple of the great goddess Diana may be considered worthless
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the people will think there is no benefit in going to the temple to worship the great goddess Diana" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: she would even lose her greatness
tn.text: Diana's greatness only comes from what people think of her.

tn.ref: whom all Asia and the world worships
tn.text: This was an exaggeration to show how popular the goddess Diana was. Here the words "Asia" and "the world" refer to the people in Asia and the known world. AT: "whom many people in Asia and in other parts of the world worship" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole|Hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here the first word "they" refers to the craftsmen who made the idols ([[:en:bible:notes:act:19:23|19:24-25]]). The second word "They" refers to the people who had gathered to hear the craftsmen who shouted.
Gaius and Aristarchus came from Macedonia but were working with Paul in Ephesus at this time.

This speaks of the craftsmen as though they were containers. Here "anger" is spoken of as if it were the contents that fill a container. AT: "they became very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"shouted aloud" or "shouted loudly"

tn.ref: The whole city was filled with confusion
tn.text: Here "city" refers to the people. The city is spoken of as if it were a container. And, "confusion" is spoken of as if it were the contents that filled the container. AT: "Then people all over the city became upset and started shouting" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This was a mob or near riot situation.
The Ephesus theater was used for public meetings and for entertainment such as plays and music. It was an outdoor semi-circular area with bench seats that could hold thousands of people.
The men who had been with Paul.
These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
Ephesus was part of the Roman empire and in the province of Asia.

The Ephesus theater was used for public meetings and for entertainment such as plays and music. It was an outdoor semi-circular area with bench seats that could hold thousands of people. See how you translated "theater" in [[:en:bible:notes:act:19:28|19:29]].
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: motioned with his hand to make an explanation
tn.text: You can make explicit that Alexander was trying to quieten the crowd. AT: "gestured to the audience to be quiet so that he could make an explanation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
He wanted to speak, but it is not clear what he was going to say.
The shouting together of the people at the same time is spoken of as though they were speaking with one voice. AT: "in unison" or "together" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The clerk of Ephesus speaks to quiet the crowd.
The words "You" and "you" refer to all the men present who were from Ephesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you|Forms of You]])
This refers to the town "writer" or "secretary."

tn.ref: what man is there who does not know that the city of the Ephesians is temple keeper ... heaven?
tn.text: The clerk asked this question to assure the crowd they were right and to comfort them. AT: "every man knows that the city of the Ephesians is temple keeper ... heaven." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion|Rhetorical Question]])
The town clerk uses "not" to emphasize that all of the people knew this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
The Ephesian people maintained and guarded the temple of Diana.

tn.ref: the image which fell down from heaven
tn.text: Within the temple of Diana was an image of the goddess that had been fashioned from a meteorite which fell from the sky. This was a rock thought to have come directly from Zeus, the ruler of the Greek gods (idols).

tn.ref: Seeing then that these things are undeniable
tn.text: "Since you know these things"
"do not do anything before you have had time to think about it"
"wild," "hasty," or "without careful thought"
The words "these men" refer to Gaius and Aristarchus, Paul's traveling companions. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:19:28|19:29]])
The town clerk finishes speaking to the crowd.

This word marks a statement that is said because of what was said previously. The town clerk had said in [[:en:bible:notes:act:19:35|19:37]] that Gaius and Aristarchus were not robbers or blasphemers.
The word "accusation" can be stated as the verb "accuse." AT: "want to accuse someone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"representatives." This refers the Roman governor's representatives who made legal decisions in court. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown|Translate Unknowns]])
This does not mean Demetrius and those with him will accuse each other. It means this is a place where people in general can speak their accusation. AT: "There people can accuse one another"

tn.ref: But if you seek anything about other matters
tn.text: "But if you have other matters to discuss"

tn.ref: it shall be settled in the regular assembly
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "let us settle it in the regular assembly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This refers to a public gathering of citizens over which the county clerk presided.

tn.ref: in danger of being accused concerning this day's riot
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "in danger of the Roman authorities accusing us of starting this riot today" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
